byline.contributor: Austin Frakt is a health economist with several governmental and academic affiliations. He blogs at The Incidental Economist, and you can follow him on Twitter at @afrakt.

abstract: The Upshot; study published in Journal of American Medical Assn finds that increased transparency with respect to health care costs has had more limited impact on decreasing prices for health care; lack of transparency has long been cited as one of drivers of health care costs.

keywords.value: Journal of the American Medical Assn
keywords.name: organizations

lead_paragraph: Research shows pricing apps and websites don’t always help patients spend less.
snippet: Research shows pricing apps and websites don’t always help patients spend less....

headline.main: Price Transparency Is Nice. Just Don’t Expect It to Cut Health Costs.
headline.print_headline: Health Price Transparency Is Failing to Rein In Costs
